column1: Arcata (from the word oket'oh in Yurok
column2: meaning "where there is a lagoon") is a city adjacent to the Arcata Bay (northern) portion of Humboldt Bay in Humboldt County

column4: United States. At the 2010 census
column6: 231. Arcata was first settled in 1850 as Union

column1: The Wiyot people and Yurok people inhabited this area prior to the arrival of Europeans
column2: and continue to live in the area to this day. "Kori" is the name for the Wiyot settlement that existed on the site of what would become Arcata. The name "Arcata" comes from the Yurok term oket'oh
column3: meaning "where there is a lagoon" (referring to Humboldt Bay)
column4: from o-
column6: plus ket'oh
column7: "to be a lagoon". The same name was also used by the Yuroks for Big Lagoon. The natives of this region are the farthest-southwest people whose language has Algic roots
column8: a language family shared with the Algonquian. The traditional homeland of the Wiyot ranged from the Little River in the north and continues south through Humboldt Bay (including the present cities of Eureka and Arcata) and then south to the lower Eel River basin. The traditional homeland of the Yurok ranges from Mad River to beyond the Klamath River in the north. Today
column9: Arcata is the headquarters of the Big Lagoon Rancheria tribe
column11: 000 m2) reservation close by. California does not have any true sovereign nation Indian tribes and all tribal lands and tribal members are subject to state and local regulations with some notable exceptions. The tribes do maintain exclusive civil jurisdiction. The Local Indian tribes operate several casinos in the area.

column1: Arcata has a cool summer Mediterranean climate (Köppen Csb)
column2: which is dominated by marine influences associated with Humboldt Bay and the Pacific Ocean. These influences make the climate in the city much cooler than that of a typical Mediterranean climate and more on par with that of an oceanic climate. On average
column3: Arcata experiences 40 to 50 inches (1
column6: though there is a short but pronounced dry season from June to September. Northerly winds keep the spring very cool and create a coastal upwelling of deep
column7: cold ocean water. This upwelling in turn results in foggy conditions throughout the summer
column8: with high temperatures commonly in the 50s and low 60s. Yet just a few miles inland the temperatures may be up to 25 degrees warmer in the summer and fall. Winter high temperatures average in the low 40s to mid-50s
column9: with lows in the mid-30s to lower 40s. Temperatures infrequently dip below 30 °F (−1 °C) in the winter
column10: and nearly as infrequently climb above 72 °F (22 °C) in the summer and fall. Regions of the world with similar temperatures to Arcata include Sitka and the Aleutians in Alaska
column13: as well as much of Scotland and elsewhere in the United Kingdom
column18: Tierra del Fuego in southern South America and the coastal areas of Norway and Scandinavia.

column1: The heart of Arcata is the Plaza. In the 1850s the Plaza was where goods destined for the Trinity County mines were loaded onto mule trains. The Plaza has a green lawn
column2: extensive flower plantings
column3: and at its center there used to be a statue of President McKinley by Haig Patigian. The Plaza is surrounded by bookstores
column4: bars
column6: restaurants
column7: and live music venues. The Plaza is also the center of Humboldt County's largest farmers' market (April through November)
column8: and serves as a major venue for local Fourth of July festivities
column9: the Arcata Main Street Oyster Festival
column10: the start of the Kinetic Sculpture Race
column11: and the North Country Fair. The North Country Fair Samba Parade has been a community favorite since 1986. The Plaza is also a popular rendezvous point for travelers who stop off in Arcata. The annual Explorations in Afro-Cuban Dance and Drum workshop is held every summer on the HSU campus. The workshop hosts the largest assemblage of Afro-Cuban folkloric music and dance masters in the United States.

column1: The statue of William McKinley has been a point of controversy since the 1970s. Opponents of the statue condemned McKinley's supposed support of settler colonialism and policies that led to the slaughter of Native Americans. Supporters of the statue emphasized its historical significance as a major part of the culture of Arcata. In February 2018
column2: the Arcata City Council voted to remove the statue from the Plaza
column3: a decision supported in November 2018 when a referendum to block the statue's removal was defeated.  In February 2019
column4: the Arcata City Council approved a measure to relocate the statue to the William McKinley Presidential Library and Museum in Canton
column6: and on February 28
column7: the statue was removed from the Plaza in preparation for its relocation.

the original inhabitants of the area
column3: call the Plaza "Goad-la-nah" for the "land a little above the water".Arcata's Minor Theater is one of the oldest movies-only theaters in the United States which is still in operation. It is also home to the Arcata Theatre.

column12: and the Jacoby Creek Forest. Arcata's community forest lands have been the subject of national media attention. The Arcata Community Forest was originally acquired by the City in order to protect the integrity of its municipal water supply. Upon acquisition in 1955
column13: The Arcata Community Forest was dedicated as the first city-owned community forest in the State of California. Since then it has served many functions including recreation
column16: and wildlife habitat. The forest serves as the headwaters of many of Arcata's urban streams. In 1979
column17: the citizens of Arcata passed the "Forest Management and Parkland Initiative." The intent of the legislation was to develop a responsible and ecologically sensitive long-term forest management program
column18: which would provide timber-harvest revenues for the acquisition and development of City parkland. In 1998 the Arcata Community Forest was the first municipal forest certified in the U.S. under the Forest Stewardship Council (FSC). Since that time additional acreage has been protected
column19: such as the 175-acre (0.71 km2) Sunny Brae Forest acquisition in 2006
column20: and the 2009 receipt of a donated 185-acre (0.75 km2) conservation easement adjacent to the Arcata Community Forest's northern boundary in the upper Janes Creek watershed.

column1: Arcata has been notably progressive in its political makeup
column2: and was the first city in the United States to elect a majority of its city council members from the Green Party.  As a result of the progressive majority
column3: Arcata capped the number of chain restaurants allowed in the city. Arcata was also the first municipality to ban the growth of any type of Genetically Modified Organism within city limits
column4: with exceptions for research and educational purposes.

column2: Arcata is in the  2nd Senate District
column3: represented by Democrat Mike McGuire
column4: and the  2nd Assembly District
column6: Arcata is in California's  2nd congressional district
column7: represented by Democrat Jared Huffman.Arcata voters are among the most Democratic in Humboldt County. In the 2008 United States presidential election
column8: Republican candidate John McCain received less than 10% of the popular vote in many Arcata precincts
column9: while in those same precincts Democratic candidate Barack Obama received 85% or more of the vote. Arcata is a hub of liberal thought typical of a college town
column10: a place where environmentalism and social activism are broadly embraced. Humboldt County fits the statewide trend of increasingly liberal coastal counties and conservative interior counties
column11: but some conservative voters remain. College students have
column13: been mayor or city council members.

column1: Arcata was the first city to have a Green Party majority in their city council. Arcata is also one of three cities in California and one of four cities in the United States to have ever held a Green Party majority in their city councils.In August 1989
column2: the voters of Arcata passed the Nuclear Weapons Free Zone Act
column3: prohibiting activities benefiting nuclear weapons contractors within city jurisdictional limits.Arcata residents are active in regional environmental protection
column4: and played a contributing role in the successful effort to preserve the Headwaters Forest from logging. The north coast region is often divided on environmental issues
column5: with conflicts arising between residents and landowners who have made a living harvesting the area's natural resources
column6: and residents aiming to preserve the region's natural habitats.

column1: Arcata is the site of Humboldt State University
column2: the northernmost campus of the 23-campus California State University system. With a student body equaling nearly half the city's total population
column3: Arcata is a classic example of a traditional "college town." The city center is .8 mi (1.3 km) from the university center and takes about 16 minutes to walk.

column1: The primary public high school is Arcata High School with a total population of 827 for the 2012–2013 school year. The high school is located at 1720 M Street in Arcata
column2: and is part of the Northern Humboldt Union High School District. The school offers a number of programs including an Advanced Placement program
column3: special programs through the Arcata Arts Institute
column4: and a variety of student clubs.

column1: The Eureka Times-Standard is the only major regional daily publication covering Arcata. The Arcata Eye was a former weekly newspaper covering Arcata and Blue Lake until it merged with the McKinleyville Press newspaper in 2013 to become the Mad River Union.  The Northcoast Environmental Center
column2: located in Arcata
column3: has published Econews as a monthly journal since 1971. HSU produces a weekly student-run paper titled The Lumberjack

column12: which is notable for being one of a select few free form radio stations still on air today. The town has a number of small 'zines and blogs that cover a variety of local issues including youth culture and homelessness.

column1: U.S. Route 101 extends north and south and bisects the city. The downtown has several overcrossings; Arcata is considered a fairly walkable community. column4: and Nevada. SR 255 Connects to U.S. Route 101 at the southern end of Arcata on Samoa Blvd. and to the west of US-101 passes through Manila. Bridge access (left at first controlled intersection) leads to Eureka through Woodley island and Indian island (using three bridges) ending on 4th (south 101) and 5th (north 101) streets in Eureka

column1: Redwood Transit System (RTS) is the major provider of public bus transportation in Humboldt County with several stops in Arcata. Arcata and Mad River Transit Service (AMRTS) is the local bus and serves Arcata and unincorporated areas such as the bottom. Dial-A-Ride service is available from Humboldt Senior Resource Center through an application process.
Transit and longhaul bus services including Amtrak and Greyhound use the Arcata Transit Center as their central interchange point for Arcata.
The closest airport is the Arcata-Eureka Airport located in McKinleyville. This airport was built by the Army Air Corps in World War II in a particularly foggy location
column2: as a site to test fog dispersal techniques. No successful dispersal method appears to have been found
column3: and after demobilization the airfield was given to the County of Humboldt as a civilian airport. This airport is one of the foggiest in the world
column4: resulting in frequent flight delays or cancellations. Some arriving flights are diverted to Redding
column6: a three-hour drive to the east
column7: or Crescent City
column8: about 90 miles (140 km) to the north.

column1: There is a deep water port in nearby Eureka. In 1854
column2: the Union Wharf and Plank Walk Company built redwood plank and rails 2.7 miles (4.3 km) out into the deeper water of Arcata Bay
column3: providing Arcata with a deep-water seaport. This was initially a horse-drawn railroad
column4: though it was later converted to steam. This eventually became the Arcata and Mad River Railroad (now defunct). Arcata's wharf is long gone
column5: and only a few piers can be seen at low tide. Some very small recreational boats can be launched from the foot of I street at the Arcata Marsh at high tide. However
column6: at low tide Arcata Bay becomes a vast mud flat and a challenge to boaters.
